title: How to cure writer's block
intro: Who were the Muses and how did they help the creative process? Neil and Alice discuss Neil's poetry and some interesting ways to deal with writer's block.
this_week_question: How does author of the Da Vinci Code, Dan Brown, deal with writer's block? Does he…
a) hang upside down from the ceiling in gravity boots?
b) clean his 6-bedroom house from top to bottom with a toothbrush?
c) run a half-marathon listening to opera music by Richard Wagner?
You'll hear the answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: not being able to write because of a psychological problem
Goddesses of creativity invoked called upon thalamus An area of the brain that controls consciousness, sleep and the senses dopamine The chemical in the brain that makes you feel good

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Alice…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I'm Neil. Have you ever written any poetry, Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: No. Have you?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh yes. I've got a sheaf of poems from my youth.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: A sheaf of something means a bundle of things, particularly paper. What about now? Are you still writing?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: No, my creative juices have dried up.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: What a shame! I would have liked to hear some of your poems! Creative juices means a flow of ideas and the subject of today's show is creativity and writer's block – which means not being able to write because of a psychological problem.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So not like tennis elbow or golfer's knee, then.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: No, Neil, because a psychological problem refers to the mind not the body. And whilst some people view writer's block as nonsense others believe it is a serious psychological condition that can get better with treatment.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, I have a question for you, Alice. How does author of the Da Vinci Code, Dan Brown, deal with writer's block? Does he… a) hang upside down from the ceiling in gravity boots? b) clean his 6-bedroom house from top to bottom with a toothbrush? Or c) run a half-marathon listening to opera music by Richard Wagner?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: I think it's c) run a half-marathon listening to Wagner. Exercise and music might get your creative juices flowing again.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, we'll find out whether you got the right answer later on in the show. But first, Alice, can you tell us where the term writer's block comes from?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, the term was coined – or invented – in 1950 by a Viennese psychoanalyst Edmund Bergler. Let's listen to Zachary Leader, Professor of English Literature at Roehampton University talking about the psychoanalytic theory of writer's block.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Zachary Leader, Professor of English Literature at Roehampton University Before writers were blocked the other metaphors that were used were things like 'drying up' … or 'being frozen' or 'stuck in a rut' and so forth. And the difference between being blocked and drying up is that in the case of blockage the problem is externalised and objectified – it's not yourself that's the problem – it's something that's outside you like an obstacle or an impediment – something that you could really cut away, and as a consequence a cure like a growth or a foreign body.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So writer's block is a metaphor for an obstacle – something external rather than internal inside of you – that's preventing you from working. Doesn't that sound like an excuse for not doing anything, Alice? 'It's not my fault – this impediment thing is getting in the way'.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. Well, impediment is another word for obstacle. But how do you cut away a foreign body that isn't actually there?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I suppose psychoanalysts have an answer for that. But seriously, I think writers probably do have a hard time. You can sit down at your desk every morning at 9 o'clock to write but that doesn't mean you're going to think of things to say. Though we're never stuck for words, are we?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Not usually, Neil, no. But did you know that the Ancient Greeks had Muses – or goddesses of creativity – to help them? Neil So… Beyoncé isn't a real muse? I've heard people say, you know, 'Beyoncé is my muse; she's such a great singer, songwriter, dancer, role model!'

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, these days, 'muse' can refer to anyone who inspires an artist, writer, or musician . But in Ancient Greece, there were nine Muses – and depending on what type of creative thing you did – philosophy, poetry, science and so on – you invoked – or called upon – that particular Muse to inspire you. Neil I call upon you, oh Alice, to enlighten us with more information about the Greek Muses.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Alright then. So let's listen to Angie Hobbs instead. She's Professor of the Public Understanding of Philosophy, University of Sheffield here in the UK – and here she is now, talking about what the Greek Muses symbolized.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Angie Hobbs, Professor of the Public Understanding of Philosophy, University of Sheffield We've seen that the Muses were connected to running water, to springs, to fountains, fluidity. So if you're musing, you are letting your mind wander, you're opening yourself up to new influences and new ideas, and not thinking in too structured a way.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Musing, letting your mind wander, thinking in a fluid, unstructured way – that all sounds very pleasant – maybe I should have another go at writing.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, according to research, some people are better at mind wandering and opening themselves up to new ideas than others. Their minds work differently – they have more dopamine in the thalamus region of the brain.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The thalamus controls consciousness, sleep and the senses and dopamine is the feel-good chemical in the brain . Is that right?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes, and having more dopamine in the thalamus enables some people to see the world in a different way – and they express this creatively – through science, music, the arts. Now, before you start musing on how much dopamine you have in your brain, Neil, perhaps you can tell us the answer to today's quiz question?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I asked: How does author of the Da Vinci Code , Dan Brown, deal with writer's block? Does he… a) hang upside down from the ceiling in gravity boots? b) clean his 6-bedroom house from top to bottom with a toothbrush? Or c) run a half-marathon listening to opera music by Richard Wagner?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: And I said c) run a half-marathon listening to opera music by Richard Wagner.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And you were wrong, Alice! The answer is a) hang upside down from the ceiling in gravity boots.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Really?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes. I expect all that increased blood flow to the brain is helpful in clearing writer's block.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. Good plan. OK, here are the words we learned today. creative juices writer's block coined impediment Muses invoked thalamus dopamine Neil So, Alice, shall I compare thee to a summer's day? Thou art more lovely… Alice That's not your poem, Neil – It's Shakespeare's! Well, and that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Neil OK, I'm off to lie on the sofa and evoke my muse. Please join us again soon! Both Bye!
